content:
The statement is confusing. I think it would be best to not give an example where "8 is the biggest value in the list", because it makes it seem like the problem is about 8 being the size of a byte and some coders will assume 8 for all test cases and end up very confused how to deal with numbers greater than 8 later on.

I just got this as a clash and didn't understand it until I came here afterwards.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept this contribution because she is smart, easy to understand and fun :-)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: quite good..

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I would like to see some of the other approaches of solving this problem.

> to sort the value
> way of sorting
word`sort` in example part is confusing, consider changing it to `group`

I was trying to find the optimal package order, which is much more difficult.
You could hightlight some parts of the description. 
The most important parts are that all packets have the size of the biggest data and data are taken in order of input.
You switched Input and Output descriptions.

I made a problem to optimize this stockage. But this problem can only be solve by testing all possible solutions. It was too hard for a clash of code. That.'s why I delete this problem and made a new one which is this one.
I understand, but it is clearly stated in the statement: "It takes the biggest size of object to be stored and chooses that to be the size of each pack"

There is better solution than to test all possibles solutions yet it is a difficult one. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bin_packing_problem
No way for a clash of code.
